abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, though the
            institutional development impact only modest. Lessons
            address once again the importance of a flexible approach to
            implementation, particularly where capacity is weak, and
            project design is overly complex. Both the Bank, and
            Government recognized these flaws, and effectively
            reallocated resources, and designed relevant activities
            (such as the Fellowship Fund), an innovation to problems of
            institutional change, conducive to a second generation
            Training Fund, now under preparation. However, the
            project's attempt to address multiple aspects of public
            sector reform, without gaining grounds in any one area,
            e.g., public expenditure management or civil service reform,
            threatened the limited absorptive capacity of the
            Government, whereas a more selective approach, focused on
            tangible gains in specific reform areas would have been
            preferable. Therefore, when implementing complex public
            sector reforms, reforming governments should not only commit
            to the process, but sequence initiatives so as to provide a
            technical foundation for successive reforms.

18156080.theme: Public expenditure, financial management and procurement,Administrative and civil service reform
18156080.trustfund:
TF022315-INTERNSHIP PROG FOR SOUTH
            AFRICANS AT THE WORLD BANK

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Second
            Institutional Development Project are to: a) address
            specific systemic management issues that now constitute
            bottlenecks to efficiency and effectiveness in the civil
            service; b) assist the Department of Statutory Bodies to
            better manage the interface between the parastatal sector
            and the Government; and c) strengthen the Malawi Institute
            of Management. The project will be implemented over a
            five-year period and has five main components: 1) improving
            civil service policy and information framework by designing,
            installing, and implementing an appropriate management
            information systems for the personnel and finance functions;
            2) strengthen the capacity of the department of personnel
            management and training by reviewing the institutional
            arrangements for determining remuneration, redesigning the
            pay structure and benefits, preparing procedure manuals for
            common service staff, developing an open performance
            appraisal system, and developing and introducing career
            paths; 3) strengthen institutional capacity of the Ministry
            of Finance by financing the installation and implementation
            of budget financing and providing support to the tax policy
            analysis unit; 4) support the Department of Statutory
            Bodies; and 5) strengthen the Malawi Institute of Management
            by supporting staff training and providing the necessary
            facilities and equipment.
